Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Micro-Harvesting RF Power using Wearable Rectennas (MH-PoWear)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed system is a power harvesting and charging unit that is integrated with textile antennas. The unique aspect of the project is the system integration of wearable textile antennas with signal processing and rectifying circuits to transfer energy into storage medium. The technology provides a means of collecting energy from air sent by base stations through radio-frequency and then storing the energy in a battery that can charge devices. Through the I-Corps program the research team aims to investigate the technology readiness for more widespread use. The prototype will be optimized and tested for various applications. It is anticipated that the findings of this proposed will provide novel textile antenna and rectifying antenna (rectenna) designs, as well as guidelines for better engineering and tailoring the system to achieve desired properties.

This project has the potential to enhance and provide enabling technology for future wearable systems for various applications such as smart wearable devices, biomedical health monitoring and situational awareness systems, by proposing a new generation of wearable rectennas. There are a number of mobile and wearable medical sensors and devices that monitor biomedical signals and send alerts to patients or care-givers, these devices could be recharged wirelessly using this technology. The technology could be integrated into a wearable device or "smart watch" that could be used in-conjunction with smart-phones and tablets. There are defense applications where this technology could be integrated into military uniforms to aid in communications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the summer of 2013 we received a grant from National Science Foundation Innovation Corps (NSF I-Corps). NSF I-Corps included the guidance of a mentoring/teaching team. We confirmed the aforementioned market through a customer discovery process with over one hundred interviews (many in the San Francisco Bay area where start-up innovation thrives) were conducted with a variety of people, each holding different titles within diverse fields of employment. At the end of the program it was concluded that there is a high demand and good market opportunity in wireless energy transfer technologies for Industrial Wireless Sensor Networks (IWSNs). Our proposed method is based on Radio Frequency (RF) wireless power transmission to transmit on-demand electrical power from a known power source to sensor nodes that are equipped with a power-receiving module. The power-receiving module collects and converts the wireless RF power into usable direct current (DC) power. The DC power is managed and distributed by a control circuit to either charge the industrial sensor directly and/or to store charge for later use. The team’s research diverged to a need to provide wireless RF powering capability to industrial sensors in prohibitively difficult environments and to any new or modified (updated) industrial infrastructure equipped with wireless sensors. The assessment of a “go decision” through NSF I-Corps provided the impetus for the creation of the proposed venture.

Industrial facilities manage hundreds to tens of thousands of individual sensor nodes scattered heterogeneously throughout their environments. Most of these sensors are traditionally wired networks, however, due to the benefits offered through wireless capability the markets are shifting towards wireless networks. IWSNs lowers the cost of materials, maintenance, and installation of the project. IWSNs also provide greater flexibility to adapt in dynamic environments, as it is a plug-and-play technology. An ON World survey of 216 industrial automation professionals, in collaboration with Industrial Supply Association, HART Communication Foundation, and Wireless Industrial Networking Alliance shows that most of IWSN technology advances over the next 5-10 years (since 2012) will be focused on reducing equipment costs, improving communications, and finding better power source solutions such as energy harvesting. The fact is that 70%-90% of future wireless sensors cannot succeed without some sort of energy harvesting technique.

The proposed RF energy-harvesting method benefits over the photovoltaic method for several reasons: (1) higher reliability (the sun does not shine all the time); (2) flexibility (RF power more easily travels through an industrial environment); (3) efficiency (light energy converted to DC power is less efficient than RF-to-DC power conversion), and (4) life time (RF technology will have much longer lifetime than solar technology). The proposed RF technology benefits over thermal and mechanical (Piezo) energy- harvesting technologies through greater flexibility. The thermal and mechanical energy-harvesting technologies need to be located where heat or mechanical energy is created from the industrial processes and this may not be where the sensor needs to be; RF does not have this limitation. Finally, RF energy transfer method benefits over the induction energy transfer method because RF power can reach much greater distances. Each technology has their niche place in industry; however, RF wireless energy solution offers a greater package of benefits over its competing technologies.
